newsitem.title: SWEDEN: SWIMMING-JOHNSON WINS WOMEN'S 400 INDIVIDUAL MEDLEY WORLD TITLE.
newsitem.headline: SWIMMING-JOHNSON WINS WOMEN'S 400 INDIVIDUAL MEDLEY WORLD TITLE.

text.p: Emma Johnson emulated compatriot Matthew Dunn to complete an Australian individual medley golden double on the opening day of the world short-course swimming championships on Thursday.
Johnson battled to victory in the women's 400 individual medley after Matthew Dunn had scored a runaway triumph in the men's event over the same distance.
The 17-year-old had a much tougher time earning her gold than Dunn, who completely spreadeagled the opposition in his race.
Johnson, fifth in the event at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, seized the lead on the opening butterfly leg and retained it on the backstroke.
Germany's Sabine Herbst, the fastest heat qualifier, overhauled the Australian on the breaststroke but Johnson fought back on the concluding freestyle and stretched away to win by nearly a second.
Johnson won in four minutes 35.18 seconds, with European short-course gold medallist Herbst second in 4:36.02 and defending champion Joanne Malar third in 4:37.46.
